lines.text: [Henry is complaing about how hard it is to get a cab in New York]
You're just like my wife, mister. You don't understand the economics of the situation.
Then teach me. I'm interested in the economics of about every situation.

Well, there are 11,000 cabs in the city - and no new permits for the next twenty-five years. Now suppose you wanna buy a cab and start hackin'... you gotta get a new permit, too. Now the tab on a new permit is eighteen thousand five hundred on the open market.
And how much did your cab cost, Mister
[looks at driver's ID]
Feinberg?
Thirty-three hundred... new.
Mm-hmm. Then that makes your investment, uh, with the permit, come to about $22,000.
Yeah. But don't tell my wife... she'll think I'm rich.
Mm-hmm. Mr. Feinberg, I'll give you $24,000 for your cab and permit.
You wanna buy the cab?
Right. But you come along with it. I'll need your services for a week, maybe two.
No, look, mister, I can't sell the cab. I need it.
Well, I figured that. So, when I leave I'll sell it back to you for... $22,000.
You wanna lose two grand just to keep your feet dry when it starts to rain?

I don't lose, Mr. Feinberg. See, I borrow the money and then I get a deduction on the loan interest and another on the depreciation and another on the loss when I sell it back to you. And you make a nice profit.
You win and I win. Uh-uh, there's gotta be a loser somewhere.
Taxman loses. He usually does on a Henry Tyroon deal.
Mister, you've just got yourself a taxi.
You don't go wheelin' 'n' dealin' for money. You do it for fun. Money's just the way you keep score.
[they have discovered that Universal Widgets has no factory, but Molly is still supposed to sell their stock and Henry says he'll help her]
Henry, you're an operator; but do you know anything about the stock market?
the reason doesn't have to make sense.
You're not thinking of anything illegal are you?
I'm never illegal. I'm just close to it.
I don't understand. How can you buy something when you don't even know what it is?

Well, you see, ma'am, Henry here is a real wheeler dealer. And a wheeler dealer is somebody that loves to find places for money to go. It's like hitchin' on to a star. You may zoom up to the sky on a mighty pretty ride.
And if the star falls?
Well, then I find some way for the, uh, government to take three-quarters of the loss.
You see, Miss Thatcher, that's the mark of a REAL wheeler dealer.
[Henry's latest oilwell has come in a "duster"]
Well, you can't sell dust, Henry. So you better hightail it up to the big city and get yourself some shoppin' money quick. Yes.
Billy Joe, is money all you ever think about?

Henry, I am an accountant. I'm supposed to think about money. So you go on up north and raise one million two startin' right now, or you're broke. Yes. Henry, you're a rich man... and a rich man can't afford to go broke.
Now, why do you suppose Mr. Bear wants me to fight off a large Texan?
You think he's got more than business on his mind?
colds, pleurisy, arthritis. I even had a guy once tell me that sex prevents cavities.
Cavities? In your teeth?
Sure. When you're tense, you have more acids in your mouth; and acids eat enamel. When you get rid of the tension, you get rid of the acids. And the best way to get rid of tension...
Don't tell me! let me guess.
Look man, if you're going to walk on my canvas, the least you can do is put a little crimson on your soles.
[the judge is reading the long list of charges brought against Henry Tyroon et al]
Mr. Vanson, this indictment seems to be a little enthusiastic!
Well, they're a pretty slippery bunch, your honor. I had to throw the book at 'em.
[in his office, Bear is telling Whitby to fire Molly to save money - she gets up from her desk]
Where is she going?
Her lunch club, I think.
Women shouldn't be allowed to have lunch clubs. We gotta keep 'em off-balance, disorganized, clawing and scratching at each other. Otherwise they might turn on us like mad dogs!
